section.title: Review -- Arithmetic Sequences
section.p: A sequence is said to be in arithmetic progression if there is a common difference between each pair of consecutive terms. Such a sequence is also called an arithmetic sequence. In the next several activities, we will be studying annuities whose payments are in arithmetic progression.
Geometric sequences were like exponential functions sampled at integral points. Arithmetic sequences are like linear functions sampled at integral points.

statement.p: The formula for the nth term of an arithmetic sequence is a_n = a_1 + d(n-1), where a_1 is the first term and d is the common difference between consecutive terms.
Compare and contrast the formula for a_n with our linear function formula f(x) = mx+b. What are similarities and what are differences?
